yoruba: Ojú ò rọ́lá rí; ó bímọ ẹ̀ ó sọ ọ́ ní Ọláníyọnu.
gold: A person only newly acquainted with wealth; he has a son and names him Ọlaniyọnu.
gen: The eyes have never seen wealth before; it gives birth to a child and names it Ọláníyọnu (Wealth is a burden).

yoruba: Ìwọ̀n eku nìwọ̀n ìtẹ́; olongo kì í gbé tìmùtìmù.
gold: The measure of the rat is the measure of the nest; a robin does not live on a cushion.
gen: The size of the rat determines the size of its hole; a large rat does not live in a small burrow.

yoruba: Ẹyẹ tó fi ara wé igún, ẹ̀hìn àdìrò ní ńsùn.
gold: Whatever bird emulates the vulture will find itself behind the cooking hearth.
gen: A bird that compares itself to a vulture sleeps behind the kitchen.

yoruba: Àwúrèbeé ní òún lè yẹ̀nà; ta ní jẹ́ tọ ọ̀nà àwúrèbe?
gold: Àwúrebe says it can make a path; who would wish to follow a path it makes?
gen: The chameleon claims it can clear the path; who would dare follow the path of a chameleon?

yoruba: Má tẹ̀ẹ́ lọ́wọ́ oníle, má tẹ̀ẹ́ lọ́wọ́ àlejò; lọ́wọ́ ara ẹni la ti ńtẹ́.
gold: Save face with members of your household and save face with complete strangers, such a person loses face with himself/herself.
gen: Do not rely on the owner of the house, do not rely on the guest; it is on one's own hand that one should rely.

yoruba: Eégún ju eégún; òrìṣá ju òrìṣà; Pààká lé oníṣàngó wọ̀gbẹ́.
gold: Some masqueraders are greater than others; some gods are greater than others; the masquerader Pààká chases the Ṣàngó worshipper into the bush.
gen: Masquerades surpass masquerades; deities surpass deities; Pààká defeated the Sango worshipper.

yoruba: “Mo yó” ńjẹ́ “mo yó,” “mo kọ̀” ńjẹ́ “mo kọ̀”; jẹun ǹṣó, àgbà ọ̀kánjúwà ni.
gold: “I am full” means “I am full”; “I decline” means “I decline”; eating with abandon, that is the father of all greediness.
gen: "I am full" means "I am full," "I am not full" means "I am not full"; eating excessively is the mark of a greedy elder.

yoruba: Àgbàlagbà kì í wẹwọ́ tán kó ní òun ó jẹ si.
gold: An elder does not wash his hand and then decide to eat more.
gen: An elder does not finish inspecting and then say they will partake in it.

yoruba: Ẹni à bá tà ká fowó-o rẹ̀ ra àdá: ó ní ìyà àdá ńjẹ òun.
gold: A person who should be sold for money to purchase a machete bemoans his lack of a machete.
gen: The person who is sold and whose money is used to buy a machete says that the machete is causing them suffering.

yoruba: Kàkà ká dọ̀bálẹ̀ fún Gàm̀bàrí, ká rọ́jú ká kú.
gold: Rather than prostrate oneself in homage or obeisance to a Hausa person, one should rather die.
gen: Instead of bowing down to a Gàm̀bàrí, we should endure and die.

yoruba: À-jẹ-ì-kúrò ní ńpa ẹmọ́n; à-jẹ-ì-kúrò ní ńpa àfè; à-jẹ-ì-kúrò ní ńpa máláàjú.
gold: Feeding-without-leaving kills the Tullberg's rat; feeding-without-departing kills the spotted grass mouse; feeding-without-departing kills the máláàjú rat.
gen: It is the inability to stop eating that kills the monkey; it is the inability to stop eating that kills the fly; it is the inability to stop eating that kills the glutton.

yoruba: A kì í fi ìka ro etí, ká fi ro imú, ká wá tún fi ta ehín.
gold: One does not use one's finger to clean one's ear passages, use it to pick one's nose, and then use it to pick one's teeth.
gen: One does not use a finger to clean the ear, then use it to clean the nose, and then use it again to pick the teeth.

yoruba: Ṣàkì ńṣe bí ọ̀rá, egungun ńṣe bí ẹran.
gold: The tripe presents itself as fat; the bone presents itself as meat.
gen: The sack acts like it is full of riches, while the skeleton acts like it is flesh.

yoruba: Ọ̀yájú-u baálé ní ńpàdé ìbòsí lọ́nà.
gold: It is a reckless home owner who is met with alarms when he ventures outside.
gen: It is the head of the household who is hasty that encounters disgrace on the way.

yoruba: Àgbàlagbà tí ò kí Ààrẹ ńfi okùn sin ara-a rẹ̀.
gold: An elder who does not greet the Ààrẹ tries a “hanging” rope for size.
gen: An elder who does not greet the warrior ties a rope around himself.

yoruba: Àì-lápá làdá ò mú; bí a bá lápá, ọmọ owú to-o gégi.
gold: It is a deficiency of biceps that blunts the machete; if one has strong biceps one can cut trees with a cudgel.
gen: It is lack of strength that prevents the cutlass from cutting; if we have strength, even a cotton child can cut wood.

yoruba: Ibi tí a fi ara sí lara ńgbé.
gold: Wherever one situates the body, there it inhabits.
gen: The English translation for "Ibi tí a fi ara sí lara ńgbé" is "Where one places oneself is where one will find comfort."

yoruba: Bí ìlàrí bá fẹ́ tẹ́, a ní kí lọba ó ṣe?
gold: When a courtier seeks disgrace, he asks, “What can the king do?”
gen: If a royal messenger wants to fall, what can the king do?

yoruba: Àfi ohun tí a kì í tà lọ́jà lẹrú kì í jẹ.
gold: The only thing a slave cannot eat is something not available in the market.
gen: A slave does not consume what is not sold in the market.

yoruba: Àṣá kì í rà kádìẹ gbé kòkòrò dání.
gold: When a kite hovers, a chicken does not hang on to an insect.
gen: A hawk does not carry a chick while holding an insect.

yoruba: Ká wí ogún, ká wí ọgbọ̀n, “Ng ò fẹ́, ng ò gbà” laṣiwèré fi ńpẹ̀kun ọ̀ràn.
gold: Whether one speaks twenty times or speaks thirty times, “I do not like it, and I will not accept it” is how the imbecile ends the discussion.
gen: To speak of inheritance and wisdom, it is by saying "I don't want it, I won't accept it" that a fool ends a matter.

yoruba: Ẹni tí a fẹ́ yàtọ̀ sí ẹni tó ní kò sí irú òun.
gold: A person one loves is different from a person who says there is no one like him/herself.
gen: The person we want is different from the one who claims there is no one like them.

yoruba: Àgùnbánirọ̀ ní ńfojúdini.
gold: It is the person taller than another who shows no respect for the other.
gen: The one who is guilty is the one who looks away.

yoruba: Ìtàkùn tó tó ọ̀pẹ kò tó pé kérin má lọ; ìtàkùn tó pé kérin má lọ Àlọ́, tòun terin ní ńlọ.
gold: A vine as thick as a palm-tree trunk will not stop an elephant; whatever vine attempts to stop an elephant from going to Alọ will go with the elephant instead.
gen: The rope that is long enough to tie a palm tree is not long enough to prevent a monkey from going; the rope that can prevent a monkey from going is the one that goes with the monkey.

yoruba: Bí a bá ńgúnyán, kòmẹsẹ̀ á yọ.
gold: If one prepares pounded yams, the uninvited should depart.
gen: When pounding yam, the yam peels will come off.

yoruba: Ọmọ àì-jọbẹ̀-rí tí ńja epo sáyà.
gold: A child new to eating stews: he shows himself by dripping palm-oil on his chest.
gen: A child who has never tasted soup before is scooping palm oil into their pocket.

yoruba: Kì í dọwọ́-ọ baba kó ló di ọwọ́ ọmọ.
gold: Responsibility does not devolve on the father only for him to say it is his son's duty.
gen: It does not leave the hands of the father to enter the hands of the child.

yoruba: Ó yẹ ẹni gbogbo kó dínwó aró, kò yẹ atọ̀ọ́lé.
gold: It is fitting for everybody to bargain to reduce the cost of dyeing clothes, but not the bed wetter.
gen: It is appropriate for everyone to reduce their complaints, but not for the lazy person.

yoruba: Ìbàjẹ́ ọjọ́ kan ò tán bọ̀rọ̀.
gold: The disgrace one incurs in one day does not disappear that soon.
gen: The damage of one day does not ruin a whole town.

yoruba: Ibi tí a ti ńpìtàn ká tó jogún, ká mọ̀ pé ogún ibẹ̀ ò kanni.
gold: Where one must recite genealogies in order to establish one's claim to inheritance, one should know that one really has no claim to patrimony there.
gen: Before we inherit a legacy, we should understand that the inheritance is not ours.

yoruba: Bí baálẹ̀-ẹ́ bá ńtàkìtì, òrógi là ḿbá ẹmẹsẹ̀.
gold: If the chief is turning somersaults, the messenger should be found standing erect.
gen: If the head of the household is struggling, it is the small tree stump that we discuss with the in-law.

yoruba: Afínjú wọ ọjà ó rìn gbẹndẹ́kẹ ọ̀bún wọ ọjà ó rìn ṣùẹ̀ṣùẹ̀; ọ̀bùn ní ó ru ẹrù afínjú relé.
gold: The fashionable person enters the market and walks in a leisurely manner; the filthy person enters the market and walks in a sluggish manner; it is the filthy person that will carry the fashionable person's load to the house for him or her.
gen: A dandy walks through the market with a confident stride, while a slovenly person walks sluggishly; the slovenly person claims to have carried the dandy's load home.

yoruba: Aáyán ati eèràá ṣígun, wọ́n ní àwọ́n ńlọ mú adìẹ àlọ la rí, a ò rábọ̀.
gold: Cockroach and ant make ready for war and say they are off to capture chicken; we see their departure, but not their return.
gen: The millipede and the ant set out on a journey, saying they are going to capture a runaway chicken, but we haven't seen them return.

yoruba: Ẹlẹ́dẹ̀ ò mẹ̀yẹ.
gold: A pig does not know what is becoming.
gen: The pig is not praiseworthy.

yoruba: Ẹ̀wọ̀n tó tó ọ̀pẹ ò tó-ó dá erin dúró; ìtàkùn tó ní kí erin má ròkè ọ̀dàn, tòun terin ní ńlọ.
gold: A chain as thick as a palm-tree cannot stop an elephant; the vine that proposes to stop the elephant from going to the grassland will go with the elephant.
gen: The chain that is long enough to go around a palm tree is not enough to stop an elephant; the rope that tells the elephant not to roam the savannah is the one the elephant takes along.

yoruba: Àfòpiná tó ní òun ó pa fìtílà, ara ẹ̀ ni yó pa.
gold: The moth that attempts to kill (put out) the oil lamp will kill itself.
gen: The moth that says it will put out the lamp will end up destroying itself.

yoruba: Àgbàlagbà akàn tó kó sí garawa yègèdè, ojú tì í.
gold: The elderly crab that enters into a bucket; it is thoroughly disgraced.
gen: The elder crab that enters a wide-mouthed container is put to shame.

yoruba: A pè ọ́ lọ́mọ erín-màgbọn ò ńyọ̀; ìwọ pàápàá ló mì í?
gold: You are described as the child of the elephant that swallows coconuts, and you rejoice; are you the one who swallows coconuts?
gen: We called you a child of the elephant and the buffalo, and you are feeling proud; are you the one they are referring to?

yoruba: Olówó ní ḿbá ọlọ́rọ̀-ọ́ rìn; ẹgbẹ́ ní ḿbá ẹgbẹ́ ṣeré.
gold: It is a rich person that keeps company with a wealthy person; only people of equal standing play together.
gen: The wealthy walk with the wealthy; peers play with peers.

yoruba: Kí ẹrú mọ ara ẹ̀ lẹ́rú; kí ìwọ̀fà mọ ara ẹ̀ níwọ̀fà; kí ọmọlúwàbí mọ ara ẹ̀ lẹ́rú Ọlọ́run ọba.
gold: Let the slave know him/herself as a slave; let the pawn know him/herself as a pawn; let the well born person know him/herself as the child of God.
gen: Let the servant recognize himself as a servant; let the apprentice recognize himself as an apprentice; let the well-bred person recognize himself as a servant of God the King.

yoruba: A kì í gbọ́n ju ẹni tí a máa dÍfá fún.
gold: One cannot be wiser than the person for whom one will consult the Ifá oracle.
gen: One cannot be wiser than the person for whom Ifá is being consulted.

yoruba: Kí ni wọ́n ti ńṣe Àmọ́dù nÍlọrin? Ewúrẹ́ ńjẹ́ bẹ́ẹ̀.
gold: What use do the people of Ilorin have for Ahmadu? Even goats are so named.
gen: What are they doing to Àmọdù in Ilorin? A goat is eating it.

yoruba: A-dá-má-lè-ṣe àdàbà tí ńdún bẹ̀m̀bẹ̀.
gold: Start-something-it-cannot-finish dove that makes bombastic noises.
gen: The dove that coos is not necessarily easy to catch.

yoruba: A-lu-dùndún kì í dárin.
gold: The dùndún player does not lead a song.
gen: The one who plays the dundun drum does not dance.

yoruba: Aláṣọ-kan kì í ná ànárẹ.
gold: A person who has only one set of clothing does not bargain until he is wet.
gen: A person with only one garment does not engage in a fire dance.

yoruba: Ọjọ́ àgbà-á kú sàn ju ọjọ́ àgbà-á tẹ́.
gold: The day an elder dies is far better than the day an elder is disgraced.
gen: The day an elder dies is better than the day an elder is disgraced.

yoruba: Ẹyẹ ò lè rí omi inú àgbọn bù mu.
gold: A bird cannot get at the liquid inside a coconut to drink.
gen: A bird cannot drink the water inside a coconut.

yoruba: “Mo mọ̀-ọ́ tán” lOrò-ó fi ńgbé ọkùnrin.
gold: “I know it all” is the reason for Orò's carrying a man away.
gen: "It is 'I know it all' that ruins a man."

yoruba: Nígbàtí à ńto ọkà a ò to ti ẹmọ́ si.
gold: When we were stacking the corn we did not stack some for the brown rat.
gen: When we were planting corn, we did not plant the stalks as well.

yoruba: Àbúrò rẹ ńdáṣọ fún ọ, o ní o ò lo elékuru; ta ní ńlo alákàrà?
gold: Your junior brother (or sister) buys clothing for you, and you say you will not wear anything with bean-grits patterns; who has the right to opt for clothing with a bean-fritter patterns?
gen: Your younger sibling is sewing clothes for you, and you say you don't wear clothes made of elékuru fabric; who then wears clothes made of alákàrà fabric?

yoruba: Bí kò sí tọ̀bùn èèyàn, ta ni ìbá jí lówùúrọ̀ tí kò bọ́jú ṣáṣá?
gold: But for a person of filthy habits, who would wake in the morning and not wash his or her face clean?
gen: If there were no good people, who would wake up in the morning and not look around cautiously?

yoruba: Àpọ́nlé ni “İyá-a Káà”; ìyá kan ò sí ní káà tí kò lórúkọ.
gold: Calling a person “Mother of the Compound” is only a mark of respect; there is no mother in the compound who does not have a name.
gen: "Àpọ́nlé ni “İyá-a Káà”; ìyá kan ò sí ní káà tí kò lórúkọ." translates to "Respect is due to 'Mother of the Town'; there is no mother in the town without a name."

yoruba: Bí iná bá dun ọbẹ̀, a dá ọ̀rọ̀ sọ.
gold: If the fire gets at the stew, the stew will burst into speech.
gen: If the stew is too hot, one blows on it.

yoruba: Àṣejù baba àṣetẹ́; ẹ̀tẹ́ ní ńgbẹ̀hìn àṣejù; àgbàlagbà tó wẹ̀wù àṣejù ẹ̀tẹ́ ni yó fi rí.
gold: Lack of moderation is the father of disgrace; disgrace comes of immoderation; a grown person who clothes himself in immoderation will find disgrace.
gen: Excessiveness is the father of failure; failure is the end result of excessiveness; an elder who wears the garment of excessiveness will end up in failure.

yoruba: Ọjọ́ kan ṣoṣo là ńtẹ́; ojoojúmọ́ lojú ńtini.
gold: It takes one day only for one to disgrace oneself; the shame is a daily affair.
gen: One can only be deceived once; every day brings new awareness.

yoruba: A kì í dákẹ́ ká ṣìwí; a kì í wò sùn-ùn ká dáràn.
gold: One does not keep quiet and yet misspeak; one does not silently contemplate the world and yet get into trouble.
gen: One does not keep silent and still speak; one does not look on and still commit a crime.

yoruba: Ṣe bóo ti mọ, ẹlẹ́wàa Ṣàpọ́n.
gold: Moderate your preening and strutting, beautiful woman of Ṣàpọ́n.
gen: As you know, the bean seller of Ṣàpọ́n.

yoruba: Gbogbo èèyàn ní ńsunkún-un Bánjọ; ṣùgbọ́n Bánjọ ò sunkún ara ẹ̀.
gold: Everybody laments Banjọ's fate, but Banjọ does not lament his own fate.
gen: Everyone is crying for Bánjọ, but Bánjọ is not crying for himself.

yoruba: Idà ahun la fi ńpa ahun.
gold: It is with its own sword that one kills the tortoise.
gen: The tortoise is killed with its own shell.

yoruba: Oúnjẹ ọmọ kékeré a máa wọ àgbà nínú; òrùka ọmọ kékeré ni kì í wọ ágbá lọ́wọ́.
gold: A youth's food can enter the stomach of an elder; it is only a youth's ring that cannot slip unto an elder's finger.
gen: The food of a small child can enter the elder's stomach; it is the ring of a small child that cannot fit an elder's finger.

yoruba: “Ẹ fà á wọlé” ló yẹ ẹlẹ́ṣin.
gold: “Lead it into the stable” is what becomes a horseman.
gen: "The appropriate thing for a horse rider is to 'pull it inside'."

yoruba: Ajá kì í lọ ságinjù lọ ṣọdẹ ẹkùn.
gold: A dog does not go into the wild to hunt a leopard.
gen: A dog does not venture into the forest to hunt a leopard.

yoruba: Alátiṣe ní ḿmọ àtiṣe ara-a rẹ̀.
gold: The person who must settle his/her affair knows best how he/she plans to go about doing so.
gen: The one who knows how to correct others should know how to correct themselves.

yoruba: Àpárá ńlá, ìjà ní ńdà.
gold: Excessive ribbing unfailingly leads to a fight.
gen: A big boil causes a fight.

yoruba: Òní, ẹtú jìnfìn, ọ̀la, ẹtú jìnfìn; ẹtu nìkan lẹran tó wà nígbó?
gold: Today, the antelope falls into the ditch; tomorrow, the antelope falls into the ditch; is the antelope the only animal in the forest?
gen: Today, the duiker is missing, tomorrow, the duiker is missing; is the duiker the only animal in the forest?

yoruba: Ìyàwó tó na ọmọ ọbàkan, ọ̀rọ̀ ló fẹ́ gbọ́.
gold: The wife who whips a relative of her husband is asking for stern rebuke.
gen: The wife who scolds another person's child is looking for trouble.

yoruba: “Ọjọ́ tí mo ti ḿbọ̀ ng ò rírú ẹ̀ rí”: olúwa ẹ̀-ẹ́ mọ ìwọ̀n ara ẹ̀ ni.
gold: “In all the days I have walked this earth I have never seen the like”: that person knows his place.
gen: "The day I will arrive, I have never seen anything like it": your master knows his limitations.

yoruba: Àì-kúkú-joye, ó sàn ju, “Ẹnuù mi ò ká ìlú” lọ.
gold: Not-assuming-the-position-of-ruler-at-all is far better than, “My word is not heeded by the people.”
gen: Not accepting a chieftaincy title is better than saying, "I cannot handle the responsibilities of the community."

yoruba: À-wín-ná-wó ò yẹni; à-gbà-bọ̀-ọ ṣòkòtò ò yẹ ọmọ èèyàn; bí kò fúnni lẹ́sẹ̀ a dòrògí; ohun ẹni ní ńyẹni.
gold: Borrowing-money-to-spend does not speak well of one; borrowed trousers do not become a person; if it is not tight around the legs it is difficult to remove; it is one's thing that fits one.
gen: What is borrowed does not befit one; wearing borrowed trousers does not suit a person; if it does not trip you, it will be too tight; what belongs to you is what truly suits you.

yoruba: Kí ni Dáàró ní kó tó sọ pé olè-é kó òun?
gold: What did Dáàró own before he claimed he was robbed?
gen: What did the night watchman do before shouting that a thief had robbed him?

yoruba: Ẹlẹ́ẹ̀ẹ́dẹ́ ńlọ ẹ̀ẹ́dẹ́, o ní “Ẹ̀ẹ́dẹ́gbẹ̀ta ni àbí ẹ̀ẹ́dẹ́gbẹ̀fà?”; èwo lo gbé níbẹ̀?
gold: A person says he has lost an unspecified amount of money, and you ask if the amount is five hundred cowries or eleven hundred cowries; which amount did you steal?
gen: The pig is going to the market, and you ask, "Is it five hundred or six hundred pigs?" Which one did you carry there?

yoruba: Ojú kì í pọ́n baálé ilé kó fọwọ́ gbálẹ̀ ilé ẹ̀.
gold: A head of a household is never so hard up that he sweeps his compound with his bare hands.
gen: The head of a household does not become so blind that he uses his hands to feel his way around his own house.

yoruba: “Ẹ kú-ulé” ò yẹ ará ilé; “Ẹ kú atìbà” ò yẹni tí ńtàjò bọ̀; ẹni tí ò kí ẹni, “Kú atìbà”-á pàdánù “Ẹ kú-ulé.”
gold: “Greetings to you, house-bound ones” is improper for the house-bound to utter; “Welcome home” is not proper for the person arriving from a trip; whoever fails to give “welcome” to the person returning does himself or herself out of “greetings, house-bound.”
gen: "Welcome home" is not appropriate for someone who lives there; "Well done for your efforts" is not suitable for someone who is running away; the person who does not greet with "Well done for your efforts" will miss out on saying "Welcome home."

yoruba: Ẹran kí la ò jẹ rí? Ọ̀pọ̀lọ́ báni lábàtà ó ba búrúbúrú.
gold: What sort of meat is it, the likes of which one has never tasted? A toad comes upon one at the swamp and cowers in fright.
gen: The translation of the Yoruba proverb "Ẹran kí la ò jẹ rí? Ọ̀pọ̀lọ́ báni lábàtà ó ba búrúbúrú." is: "What kind of meat have we not eaten before? When a frog gets stuck in the mud, it struggles desperately."

yoruba: A-binú-fùfù ní ńwá oúnjẹ fún a-binú-wẹ́rẹ́-wẹ́rẹ́.
gold: A volatile-tempered person secures food for a mild-tempered person.
gen: It is the one who is extremely angry that seeks food for the one who is only slightly angry.

yoruba: Pẹ̀tẹ̀pẹ́tẹ̀ Ìjèṣà, ó ta sẹ́ni lára kò wọ́n.
gold: The mud of the Ìjèṣà: it splashes on one and will not be washed off.
gen: The Ijesha mud, it splashes on one but does not stain.

yoruba: Ta ní ńjẹun tájá ńjùrù?
gold: At whose dinner table is the dog wagging its tail?
gen: Who is eating that the fish is complaining?

yoruba: Afínjú ní ńjẹ iwọ; ọ̀mọ̀ràn ní ńjẹ obì; màrí-màjẹ ní ńjẹ awùsá.
gold: It is a finicky person that eats iwọ;
gen: A fastidious person eats the ìwọ fruit; a wise person eats the kola nut; a glutton eats the awùsá nut.

yoruba: Bí a kò bá tó ìyà-á kọ̀ tí à ńkọ̀ ọ́, àjẹkún ìyà là ńjẹ.
gold: If one lacks the means to reject suffering and attempts to reject it, one's suffering simply multiplies.
gen: If we do not measure the suffering we are enduring, we end up experiencing excessive suffering.

yoruba: A kì í bọ òrìṣà lójú ọ̀fọ́n-ọ̀n; bó bá dalẹ́ a máa tú pẹpẹ.
gold: One does not sacrifice to a god in the presence of a house rat; otherwise, when night falls it invades the rafter shelves.
gen: One does not worship the deity with empty hands; if one tries, the offering will scatter.

yoruba: Ìwọ̀sí ní
gold: X
gen: The translation of "Ìwọ̀sí ní" from Yoruba to English is "The future will tell" or "Time will tell."

yoruba: Àgbà tí kò lẹ́sẹ̀ nílẹ̀ a lọ́gbọ́n nínú.
gold: An elder that has no substance should have cunning.
gen: An elder who is not grounded in wisdom is lacking in understanding.

yoruba: À ńjá ìbàǹtẹ́ ẹ̀ lẹ́hìn, ó ńjá tará iwájú.
gold: His loincloth is being stripped from behind, yet he is stripping those of the people ahead of him.
gen: We are adjusting the loincloth at the back, while it is loosening at the front.

yoruba: Ẹ̀yá ló bí mi, ẹkùn ló wò mí dàgbà, ológìnní gbà mí tọ́; bí kò sẹ́ran lọ́bẹ̀ nkò jẹ.
gold: I was born of a monkey; I was raised by a leopard, I was adopted by a cat; if there is no meat in the stew I will not eat it.
gen: The antelope gave birth to me, the leopard raised me, the hunter trained me; if it is not meat, I do not eat it.

yoruba: À-jẹ-tán, à-jẹ-ì-mọra, ká fi ọwọ́ mẹ́wẹ̀ẹ̀wá jẹun ò yẹ ọmọ èèyàn.
gold: Eating-absolutely-everything, eating-with-abandon, eating with all ten fingers is unworthy of human beings.
gen: Eating extravagantly without self-restraint, using all ten fingers to eat, is not appropriate for a human being.

yoruba: Òkùnkùn ò mẹni ọ̀wọ̀; ó dÍfá fún “Ìwọ́ tá nìyẹn”?
gold: Darkness does not know who deserves deference; it consulted the oracle Ifá for “Who might you be?”
gen: Darkness does not recognize a person of honor; it is the Ifá oracle that was consulted for "Who are you?"

yoruba: Bí ayá bá mojú ọkọ, alárìnnà a yẹsẹ̀.
gold: When the wife has got to know the husband, the marriage broker makes way.
gen: When the wife and husband are in harmony, the mediator steps aside.

yoruba: Ẹni à ńgbé gẹ̀gẹ̀ ni yó ba ara-a rẹ̀ jẹ́.
gold: It is the person who is revered that will disgrace himself or herself.
gen: The person who is being carried like a log will harm themselves.

yoruba: Tẹ̀tẹ̀ kì í tẹ́.
gold: Spinach is never disgraced.
gen: The creeping plant does not fall.

yoruba: Ẹní bá dẹ ojú-u rẹ̀ sílẹ̀ á rímú-u rẹ̀.
gold: Whoever gazes downwards with will see his or her nose.
gen: The one who closes his eyes will see his nose.

yoruba: Onígẹ̀gẹ́ fìlẹ̀kẹ̀ dọ́pọ̀; onílẹ̀kẹ̀ ìbá gbowo, ko rọ́rùn fìlẹ̀kẹ̀ so.
gold: The person with goitre offers a ridiculously low price for beads; were the beads seller to accept her offer she would have no neck to string the beads around.
gen: The one who cuts beads strings them together; if the bead owner were to pay, it would not be easy to string the beads.

yoruba: Bí a bá ti mọ là ńdé; a-láì-lẹ́ṣin kì í dé wọ̀nwọ̀n.
gold: One arrives according to one's worth; a horseless person does not arrive with the noise of hoofs and stirrups.
gen: As we know, we prepare; one without a horse does not reach the destination.

yoruba: “Mo mọ̀wọ̀n ara-à mi” kì í ṣẹ̀rẹ̀kẹ́ èébú.
gold: “I am jealous of my dignity” does not hurl insults at others.
gen: "I know my limitations" is not an easy insult.

yoruba: A kì í bá ọba pàlà kí ọkọ́ ọba má ṣàn-ánni lẹ́sẹ̀.
gold: One does not share a farm boundary with a king without getting one's feet gashed by the king's hoe.
gen: One does not engage in a dispute with a king without the king's staff being used to strike them on the leg.

yoruba: Bí eegbọ́n bá ṣo ayínrín nímú, adìẹ kọ́ ni yó ja.
gold: If a tick clings to a fox's nose, it is not a chicken that will remove it.
gen: If the elder brother snorts sand, it is not the chicken that will sneeze.

yoruba: À-sẹ́-kú làgbàlagbà ńsẹ́ ọ̀ràn.
gold: Denying-until-death is the way a venerable person denies a matter.
gen: It is when the situation is almost hopeless that an elder intervenes.

yoruba: Ìṣẹ̀ ò ti ibìkan mú ẹni; ìyà ò tibìkan jẹ èèyàn; bí o bá rìnrìn òṣì, bí o bá ojú ìṣẹ́ wọ̀lú, igbá-kúgbá ni wọn ó fi bu omi fún ẹ mu.
gold: Destitution does not attach to one at a particular place; suffering does not attack a person at a particular place; if one walks like a wretch into a town, if one looks like a loser when one enters a town, it is with a miserable calabash that the people will offer one water to drink.
gen: Poverty does not hold a person from one place; suffering does not afflict a person from one direction; if you wander in poverty, if you enter a town with the appearance of hardship, they will give you water to drink in a calabash.

yoruba: Oòrùn, kó tìẹ wọ̀ ká má bàá Ọlọ́jọ́ wí.
gold: Sun, go set so one does not blame the owner of the day.
gen: The sun, set so that we do not blame the Creator of the day.

yoruba: Mo dàgbà mo dàgó, aré ọmọdé ò tán lójúù mi.
gold: I have become old and wise, but childish play has not ceased to appeal to me.
gen: I have grown and matured, but the antics of children are not lost on me.

yoruba: Olóbìnrin kan kì í pagbo ìja.
gold: A person who has only  one wife does not form a circle for a fight.
gen: A woman does not break up a fight.
